for anyone confused about the explanation of the computation of the rows and columns of C:  > To compute a column of C, multiply all rows of A by a column/vector of B, aka sum of dot product of rows of A against column of B. The resulting column of C is a linear combination of the columns of A.  > To compute a row of C, multiply all columns of B by a row of A, aka sum of dot product of row of A against columns of B. The resulting row of C is a linear combination of the rows of B.

I think I'll never understand why math in North America is so computation-heavy. I don't give a ***k about how to compute the product of two matrix or how to invert one using Gauss-Jordan elimination. We are in the 21st century and we have these incredible machines called "computers" designed, guess what, to compute things. The very first thing to do in a linear algebra course is to define the words "linear" and "algebra". Then introduce vector spaces, which is the essence of linear algebra. Then linear maps, bilinear forms, inner products, etc. One can mention that matrices are a way to represent the objects studied during the course in a certain basis, but that's all. They should not be the main object of study. The detail of the manipulation of these matrices, the Gauss-Jordan elimination method, the computation of the determinant, etc., should be taught in a separate numerical analysis course. It has nothing to do with linear algebra. I deeply and viscerally hate this constant emphasis on technicalities of computation rather than on the understanding and on the theory.

Math courses are computation-heavy because they're primarily taken by engineering and science students who are more interested in building or studying stuff related to their own area of concentration than in engorging in math proofs. Even though it might not be as strictly foundational as beginning by studying vector spaces and mappings, for students it might be easier to get hooked on by knowing that linear algebra is related to the solution of systems of linear equations, which they might be able to tie to their previous experiences with elementary algebra.  Being able to see and try out the methods used to manipulate arrays, vectors, and matrices can make students feel like they're getting something tangible out of linear algebra, instead of being hit head-on by a wave of purely abstract stuff. Now, I know pure math students will be the exception to much of this, since they might be more interested in formal proofs and the construction of systems than in number-chunking exercises, but I want you to bear in mind that most people see math only as a tool for other stuff, rather than something to be explored for its own sake.

You are right but also remember Rows before Columns.   First because an m X n matrix has m, the first number, rows and n, the second number, columns.  Rows before columns  Second because premultiply row-wise to get rows, and post-multiply column-wise to get columns. Rows before, columns after. That is,  R1 A = R2 means if weights for a linear combination are in a row in R1, the sum of weighted rows of A becomes that row in R2.   A C1 = C2 means if weights for a linear combination are in a column in C1, the sum of weighted columns of A becomes that column in C2.   Rows before columns.

In 25:50 , An alternative way to understand that matrix A doesn't have an Inverse is to visualize the matrix in a cartesian plane.  The matrix is composed of two vectors: (1,2) & (3,6). Plotting these two vectors you will realize that they are parallel. Thus, they don't create a 2D area. They are a 1D line, one on top of the other. Reversing such vectors (applying the inverse matrix) would result in a  zero-D point, specifically (0,0). Thus, there is no inverse matrix for matrix A.   Note: Finding that the determinant of the matrix A is equal to 0 would quickly depict this same process.

note: there are 5 ways to think of matrix multiplication. 1. cij=Sum[aik*bkj,{k,1,n}] 2. (Matrix*column=column), Columns of C are combination of columns of A. 3. (row*Matrix=row), Rows of C are combination of rows of B. 4. AB=sum of (columns of A)(rows of B). 5. We can cut matrix into blocks.

One easy way to understand matrix multiplication using Machine Learning Classification strategy: 1. Rows of C are combinations of rows of B: just treat it as classification with one example but mutiple classifiers; 2. Columns of C are combinations of columns of A: just treat it as classification with multiple examples but only one classifier; 3. sumOf(Columns of A * Rows of B): jut treat it as classification with multiple examples and mutiple classifiers but should be added up with all features in data examples.

26:37 this is for those who did not understand the first reasoning behind why the inverse was not possible. A=[1 3;2 6]   X is supposed to be the identity matrix so that A^-1A=I You can approach it this way: A*(1st col. of X)= [1;0] which is same as  1st col. of A* X11+ 2nd col of A*X12 but the problem is that since the first column and second column of A are dependent vectors (that is [1;2] and [2,6] differ only in length and not in the direction. It's impossible that a linear combination of them can result in a vector that has a different slope (as is [1;0]) I hope this helps.

@TahlilAhmedchowdhury  we're adding the columns of A together element-wise. So the top most number of each column is added together to make the top most number of C. This is done for the numbers in the next row down and so on. Now, we're not just adding the original numbers, but weighted versions where the weight is given in X. Put another way, it's fine that A has 3 columns and C only one, just as 1+2+3=6 has three numbers on the left and only one on the right. It's because the three on the left are summed and become a single number, matching the dimension of the right side.

[2021-08-26] At 38:45 he asks: "What are the elimination steps ?" and then proceeds to determine the steps.  The first step seeks to obtain a zero at row-2-column-1 (and thus the multiplication matrix for this step might be called E21) by subtracting 2-times-row-1 from row-2. As per the previous lecture ("#2: Elimination with matrices"), we can express this E21 as a matrix (to be multiplied by to the left of the augmented-A matrix):  E21 is:      [ 1   0]     [-2   1]  and E21 times augmented-A gives (as written on the blackboard after the first step arrow, i.e. at 39:37):      [ 1   3   1   0]     [ 0   1  -2   1]  We can see that we have indeed obtained a zero in row-2-column-1.

Gauss would quit, but Jordan keeps going on with the next elimination step, seeking to obtain a zero at row-1-column-2 (and thus the multiplication matrix for this second step might be called E12) by subtracting 3-times-row-2 from row-1:  E12 is:      [ 1  -3]     [ 0   1]  and E12 times (the-augmented-A-matrix-after-modification-by-the-first-step) gives:      [ 1   0   7  -3]     [ 0   1  -2   1]  at which point Jordan is also satisfied.

Steps are multiplied to the left, in order:      second-step-matrix times (first-step-matrix times augmented-A-matrix) equals identity-matrix-augmented-with-what-had-better-be-the-inverse-of-A  But matrix multiplication obeys the associative law, so we can move the parentheses around:      (second-step-matrix times first-step-matrix) times augmented-A-matrix equals identity-matrix-augmented-with-what-had-better-be-the-inverse-of-A  What we have in parentheses now, i.e. (second-step-matrix times first-step-matrix), is the "overall elimination matrix", E.  (We should note the order of the operands of the multiplication giving the overall-elimination-matrix: the second-step-elimination-matrix goes to the left and the first-step-elimination-matrix goes to the right.)   In this case, E is E12 times E21.  If we perform the multiplication of E12 and E21, we obtain E:      [ 7  -3]     [-2   1]  If we perform the multiplication of E and A (or the multiplication of A and E, though we should remember that, generally speaking, matrix multiplication does not obbey the commutativity law), we obtain I (the identity matrix).  This is another confirmation (albeit for this particular case only) that E is the inverse of A.

# in Honor of Gilbert Strang and Richard Feynman import numpy as np  # returns the index of the value with largest absolute value past starting # from point s in the arr, which is the where we start in the column in  # below algos case def largestAbs(arr, s):     i = s     curMax = abs(arr[s])     for n in range(s, len(arr)):         if abs(arr[n]) > curMax:             curMax = abs(arr[n])             i = n      return i, curMax  # Guass - Jordan Elimination for finding the inverse of a matrix # note that this assumes that M is a Numpy array def GJElim(M):     # check if its square     n = len(M[0])     if len(M[:,0]) != n:         return None      # part of the Gauss - Jordan elimination algorithm     I = np.identity(n)     # we do this in order to bring the right hand side of the linear system along      # for the ride     A = np.concatenate((M, I), axis=1)      # we will loop through all the columns     for j in range(n):         '''         find max value along with its index; if max value is 0 then no pivot available and          thus there is not an inverse; so we return None          if there is a pivot available, then go ahead and do a row exchange           IF the max value is NOT already in the diagnol  aka --> when the row and col           value are ==          '''         i, maxVal = largestAbs(A[:, j], j)         if maxVal == 0:             return None         elif i != j:             temp = np.array(A[i])             A[i] = A[j]             A[j] = temp          # now multiply row j  --> M[j] * 1/M[j,j]         # this makes the diagnol value have a 1, thus allowing us to easily eliminate the          # other values in col         A[j] = A[j] * (1 / A[j,j])          for r in range(n):             # if r == j then this means we are on the diagnol; we only eliminate cols above              #  and below             if r != j:                 A[r] += A[j] * -A[r,j]      return A     S = np.array([[1, 3],               [2, 7]]) F = GJElim(S) print(F)

At t = 21:00, Strang covers the definition of inversion (and at 32:00 he gives an example): first suppose A is an n x m matrix. Then if you have a left inverse L that acts on A, it will produce an identity matrix, call it I_n; similarly, If you have a right inverse R, when A acts on R it will also produce an identity matrix, call it I_m. So a Matrix is non-singular (sometimes mistakenly called regular) only if  m = n, A is square, and det(A) (does not) = 0. In particular, if the matrix A have full rank = n, all its columns and rows would be independent, so A would be invertible.
